moves.1. d4 d5 2. c4: The Queen's Gambit, my favourite opening.
moves.3. Nc3 c5: I am unfamiliar with this line - the Tartakower, I think it is called.
moves.4. cxd5 exd5 5. Nf3 Nf6 6. Bg5 Be7 7. dx: This is all theory, walking along the beaten track. Now watch while my opponent (Black) drags us off into the wilderness!
moves.8... Qb6: !!!!! Black does not recapture! At first, I think he has blundered. But then I realise that he can play 9...Bxf2 . Then after 10. Kd2 Qd4  or Qe3 . Either way, I escape to c2, and then I think I can squirrel away into the queenside. But I didn't really feel safe with that. What can I do to stop him? Firstly, 9.Na4 or Nxd5 suggest themselves, but they don't really stop the attack I have just detailed. I see now that I SHOULD HAVE PLAYED 9.Bd4, blocking the attack and sneaking away with the material too! But at the time I saw no way of stopping the attack, so I hoped that it would not be fatal and played the greedy move 9.Bxg7.
moves.10. Kd2 Qe3+: The pressure is still on, but I am not panicking just yet...
moves.11. Kc2 Bf5+: I didn't see that one coming. Not I really am scared. My king now has no option but to escape to the queenside, but instead of being hidden behind the pawns as I had hoped it will be exposed in front of the pawns.
moves.12. Kb3 Qb6+: My king is pushed up against the side.
moves.13. Ka3 Bc5+: The forced checkmate looms ever closer as my opponent's pieces stab my king with attack lines.

gameName: I came, I saw, I conquered! (Julius Caesar)
